content:
We subjected every pound of Pendle Borough Council's published spending data to rigorous automated analysis — 48,785 transactions totalling £127 million since April 2021. Despite having the lowest total spend of the three East Lancashire councils, Pendle has the highest transaction volume by a wide margin, with an average transaction of just £2,604 compared to Burnley's £11,616.

This pattern of many small payments, rather than fewer large ones, creates its own risks — and our analysis found that Pendle has the most duplicate payment groups of any council we examined.

The Headline Numbers

Finding Value
Total spend analysed£127,000,000
Total transactions48,785
Unique suppliers3,019
Average transaction value£2,604
Payments to suppliers during Companies House breaches£37,800
Likely duplicate payments£2,700,000
Suspected split payments£19,500,000
Year-end spending spike (Financial Services)2.7x average

1. The Small Payment Problem

Pendle processes 48,785 transactions — more than double Hyndburn (29,802) and nearly 2.5 times Burnley (19,865). Yet its total spend of £127M is the lowest of the three. This means an average transaction of just £2,604, compared to £7,080 at Hyndburn and £11,616 at Burnley.

High volumes of small transactions increase administrative costs, create more opportunities for errors, and make oversight harder. The sheer volume may explain why Pendle has the most duplicate groups.

2. Companies House: The Cleanest Record (But Not Clean)

Pendle paid £37,800 to 4 suppliers during active Companies House breaches — the lowest of the three councils. All four were rated high severity. While this is significantly better than Hyndburn (£1.1M) or Burnley (£223.9K), even one payment to a non-compliant company should trigger a review.

3. 1,311 Duplicate Groups — The Most of Any Council

Despite the lowest total spend, Pendle has 1,311 high-confidence duplicate groups totalling £2.7 million. By comparison, Burnley has 503 groups and Hyndburn has 940. The high volume of small transactions appears to drive this — more payments mean more opportunities for duplication.

4. £19.5 Million in Suspected Split Payments

Our analysis flagged 777 instances of potential payment splitting — where payments to the same supplier appear to be artificially divided to stay below approval thresholds. At £19.5 million, this is the highest split payment exposure of the three councils.

5. Financial Services Year-End Spike

The Financial Services department spent 2.7 times its monthly average in March, representing £1.7 million above normal spending. While less extreme than Hyndburn's 12.9x spike, it still represents a significant "use it or lose it" pattern.

Methodology

This analysis uses the same automated pipeline applied to Burnley and Hyndburn councils. Pendle's data covers transactions from April 2021 onwards, with a £500 disclosure threshold. All matching and anomaly detection uses identical parameters across all three councils for fair comparison.

All figures derived from publicly available Pendle Borough Council spending data. Full methodology available on request.
